This pull request doesn't merge cleanly anymore, can you please close it?

Sorry for not replying to this earlier, but pull requests are not currently monitored as the Kafka project uses JIRA and Review Board for contributions. There is a plan to change this and we would like to close stale PRs before we start. Unfortunately we can't do it ourselves (a JIRA needs to be filed with Apache Infra) so your help is appreciated.

If this change is still relevant, please see http://kafka.apache.org/contributing.html. Alternatively wait until the new approach based on GitHub pull requests is in place (hopefully soon).

Can you please close this pull request since the issue has been solved (we can't do it ourselves without asking Apache Infra via a ticket).

@fsaintjacques, for Apache projects, no-one but Apache Infra has write permission to the repository (including pull requests and issues). So, either you (the author) must close it, or we must file a ticket asking Infra to do it.

This pull request doesn't merge cleanly anymore, can you please close it?

If this change is still relevant, please see http://kafka.apache.org/contributing.html. Alternatively wait until the new approach based on GitHub pull requests is in place (hopefully soon).
@tedxia, can you please close this PR since a patch was attached to JIRA (we can't do it ourselves without asking Apache Infra via a ticket)?
@jhspaybar, we are testing contributions via GitHub, but it's not the official way yet. See https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Contributing+Code+Changes for the proposed approach.
@nssalian, it may be a good idea to fix your commits so that there isn't a "Revert" commit in the pull request.

The proposed documentation for the GitHub-based process (it's not official yet):

https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Contributing+Code+Changes

Regarding squashing of commits, it depends on whether it's useful to have separate commits or not (i.e. does each commit represent a self-contained change that makes sense on its own, compiles and passes the tests?).

The merge script will squash the commits into one, but it will also include a reference to each individual commit. As such, commits that don't add any value should be squashed before the merge step.
Can you please close this since the change has been integrated?
Can you please close this since it's been integrated?
@rekhajoshm, this is still open. Can you please close it?

This avoids adding extra dependencies to the client jar as we discussed, but we will still need to fix the releaseTarGz and uploadArchives targets.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #25](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/25/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good
Can you please close the change has been integrated a while back? Thanks.
LGTM

@hachikuji, I think it would be better for the commit message to indicate that it's fixing a problem in `Fetcher`. Someone reading the commit message may think it's just a flaky test issue otherwise. I understand that you just used the JIRA title. May be worth updating that too.

@jhspaybar, according to the guidelines, the PR title should be:

`KAFKA-2236; Offset request reply racing with segment rolling`

You can use different text than the JIRA title if it represents the issue better, but the JIRA id must come first followed by a semi-colon.

Also, the PR text is included in the squashed commit, so it's better not to have the paragraph about the mechanics of the contribution.

Note that both the title and PR text can be edited without having to resubmit.

Finally, regarding the change, it looks good to me (based on the comments in the JIRA) aside from the tests issue. I don't know how easy it is to test this, but maybe someone else can help.
A minor comment, LGTM otherwise.
You should set the status in JIRA to "Patch Available" (it's done via the unintuitive "Submit Patch" button).
Made it explicit in ConsumerRecord constructor key parameter javadoc that null key is allowed, as suggested by @ijuma.

@ijuma thanks for reviewing my patches. Projects have different rules, what about Apache Kafka - is it a must to have a JIRA ticket for every commit? Am I supposed to create a JIRA ticket along with PR? Would it just speed up accepting of changes?

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #31](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/31/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

@guozhangwang I haven't been able to reproduce the test time out. Although I'm reluctant to introduce any additional instability in the tests (which is getting to be a real pain), I think the test failure may not be related to this patch. And this should fix the NPE causing ConsumerBounceTest to fail occasionally (which I have been able to reproduce).

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #32](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/32/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

The change is backward compatible, all modified functions have a default so it should not break any scripts. 

If a user enabled zookeeper authentication by adding "java.security.auth.login.config=some-jaas-file.jaas"  where some-jaas-file.jaas has Client section, then they are essentially locking all broker zookeeper entries so only users/processes that has access to the keytab or knows the digest user/secret listed in Client section can modify those entries. Please see https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/ZOOKEEPER/Zookeeper+and+SASL Section "JAAS conf file: Kerberos authentication".

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #33](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/33/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

@gwenshap Given you were the original author of the jira , it would be great if you can review this. Also let me know if you think adding a SECUTIRY.md at top level which describes how kafka zookeeper interaction and kafka znodes can be secured with acls makes sense.
I'll be happy to review, but - doesn't this depend on Kafka having kerberos tickets first? Otherwise we can't really check if Kafka manages to access these znode.

@gwenshap or @guozhangwang, any chance one of you could merge this? It's a simple change and it has been reviewed by a couple of people.

[kafka-trunk-git-pr #44](https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr/44/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good
+1. @ymatsuda was also requesting this feature.

@sslavic Usage doesn't seem to match the comment (not due to your change). It looks like KafkaConsumer.poll returns a single ConsumerRecords instance which contains all partitions for all topics, not just a particular topic. Perhaps we should change the comment to reflect that usage, and maybe separately we can consider if poll() should return List<ConsumerRecords> instead?
LGTM.

@hachikuji IMO after my change gets merged, it will match reality. ConsumerRecords has records grouped per partition (TopicPartition) and not per topic. Partitions included in ConsumerRecords can belong to different topics.

@sslavic I think my confusion is about the phrase "There is one for every," which I interpreted to mean one instance of ConsumerRecords (which doesn't match current usage). If it means something else, perhaps we just clarify what it refers to.

@ijuma and @eribeiro thanks for reviewing.
@eribeiro your suggestion doesn't seem to compile. Tried with both explicitly setting type for emptyList() and by having compiler infer it - doesn't work with ternary operator.
